narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the issues surrounding primate conservation, such as deforestation, illegal trade, and how national parks are often under siege for their valuable natural resources. I also learned the basics of primate anatomy, social structure, and behavior.
I was able to learn a lot about the different threats that primates face and different conservation methods to help them.
Important topics in conservation and human development; political and ethical issues; case studies
How to approach questions from an anthropology perspective while learning about a range of topics relating to primates and the environmental issues that endanger them.

I not only learned about the efforts going into primate conservation around the world and how different species are at different levels of risk, but the true web of factors that aid or deter conservation efforts. For example, we had much discussion about indigenous rights, environmental management, and armed conflict, that can all effect the way conservation takes place. It was truly an enriching class, whose content shaped my future interests.
I learned so much about primates and the necessity of conservation in this time. There are so many reasons to help not only primates, but also ourselves with keeping the Earth alive.

I gained a much greater knowledge of the diversity and distribution of primate species, their biology, the threats facing them, and various types of conservation efforts aimed at them. I especially  appreciated the emphasis on ethical issues in conservation.
Reading and analyzing scientific papers and studies, approaching conservation from multiple viewpoints, writing short response articles to papers, discussion of reading topics.

Background knowledge on primate ecology, conservation, Indigenous rights, etc. Discussions require critical thought and touched on a number of issues surrounding conservation in areas where non-human primates exist.
I developed better skills in research and essay writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the course's biggest strength was that the content itself is interesting. Each class talked about very different things ranging from civil war in Africa to agriculture in Brazil.
Brilliant course - best I took this semester.
This course is truly incredible - I don't believe there is anything to improve. It was rich with discussion, with a perfect amount of readings and videos to prepare for class.
I appreciated how the ratio of discussion to lecture and the format of discussions (whole class vs breakout rooms) was adjusted somewhat according to the class' preferences.
Stregnths were the combined lecture and discussion format and the weekly small assignments, there was good balance of work in this course. One weakness is that discussion is hard when virtual.

Strengths: Good mix of large and small group discussion, assignments were fun and insightful, guest lectures were also very engaging, I also enjoyed that the two professors switched off every other lecture because we had the opportunity to hear about different research methods and different work being done in different areas and with different primate species

Weaknesses: I liked the discussion posts but think they would be better as optional or should replace a few of the assignments throughout the semester

Strengths: interesting and engaging, manageable and interesting readings and homework, discussion in lectures, knowledgeable and understanding professors always willing to help you learn more, extremely accommodating with this difficult year, 2 professors with different areas of interest
Weaknesses: at first it was difficult to get involved in discussion

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was really helpful to record the lectures so I could rewatch when necessary.
The professors were patient and understanding of students individual circumstances.
There was different forms of discussion, with small groups (in breakout rooms), large class discussions, and guest speakers. Furthermore, we had a discussion poll and frequent reflections.
I thought that both the lecture and discussion portions of the class were well adapted to Zoom.

The discussion parts of the class could be improved by having more small group discussion. The discussions held during class were mostly with the whole class of about 25 people, and the same few people would be talking most of the time.
The recording of lectures was very helpful and also providing all readings on Canvas was really helpful
At first it was difficult to get involved in discussion; beginning with small groups then transitioning to large groups might have helped because it's awkward in a virtual setting

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. It is a really interesting class that does not overload you with work if you are just looking for an anthropology credit and do not need this for a major. The teacher's worked well together, the lectures were interesting, and I enjoyed the dissuasions with my peers.

I would recommend this course to another student if primate conservation is something that interests them. The class itself was pretty easy going and it was mostly discussions and lectures. The assignments are also relatively short and get you to engage critically with some of the topics in the class.
Yes! Although there are a decent number of assignments, they are not particularly long so as long as you attend lectures you can easily do them.
Yes - the class covers a lot of diverse topics beyond primate conservation that are useful to know in any field.
Yes, content was interesting, professor is very engaged, grading was very lenient and work was minimal. But you will get out of it only what you put into it.
Yes, interesting topics, kind professors, and small assignments spread out over the semester
Absolutely. Requires no prerequisite knowledge and was a meaningful experience that actually improved my knowledge and thinking skills.
YES
Yes!! It was an amazing and life-changing course and I'm so happy that I took it.
Yes, to anyone interested in the science or ethics of conservation, or to anyone interested in primates
I would recommend this course, it was interesting and engaging and the readings and assignments were relevant and interesting.

This course is incredibly engaging. The exposure to general conservation and primate conservation was very insightful and exciting to learn about. With the current environmental crisis, this class feels very timely in thinking about what individuals can do and about different conservation methods being used.
Yes! Whether you have experience in this area or not, it's a great course.
